Award.AwardTitle: Exoplanets with HET and Kepler: Multiplanet Systems Near and Far
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI and his team plans to use the upgraded Hobby-Eberly Telescope High Resolution Spectrograph (HET HRS) to obtain high resolution (1-2 m/s) spectra of stars, and to use the Kepler database in order to discover new planets using the radial velocity technique. They will first measure the throughput of the newly upgraded HET HRS system, establish a target list from Kepler, and then they will conduct a census of gas and ice giants out to 2 AU for hundreds of host stars, including searches for inner rocky Earth-analog planets. The PI has institutional access to the HET.

This project will have broader impacts for the exoplanet community in that the PI will maintain and expand the online Exoplanet Orbit Database and Exoplanet Data Explorer web tools with the help of two undergraduate research students. He also plans to add educational activities to the websites. He will also mentor a postdoctoral associate in research and management.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award was used to understand the limitations of the "iodine" method of precisely measuring the motions of stars so that we can detect and measure the orbits and masses of planets orbiting them. We had originally planned to apply this work to an instrument at the Hobby-Eberly Telescope, but delays in the construction of that instrument required us to instead work on the HIRES instrument at Keck Observatory. 

We found that the dominant limitations of the method are related to the precision of our understanding of the true spectra of the stars themselves and of the spectrum of the iodine gas in our calibration cells. This understanding is guiding the development of software and hardware programs to improve the method's precision in next-generation instruments that will detect Earth-mass planets around nearby stars.

This award also funded the maintenance of the Exoplanet Orbit Database at exoplanets.org, a compendium of good orbital parameters for all of the exoplanets known to orbit other stars. This resources is used by researchers, educators, and members of the public around the world to understand the properties of exoplanets, and is now the primary source of metadata for exo.mast, the exoplanet-orbit services offered at the Barbara A. Mikulski Archive for Space Telescopes at the Space Telescope Science Institute.

Eleven peer-reviewed publications report work done under this grant (at least in part), including the announcement of our discovery of a planet with an orbit and mass similar to Jupiter orbiting a star similar to the Sun, only the tenth such system ever discovered. This work also supported the characterization of many other long-period, gas giant planets around stars near the Sun.

Several students were supported with this award, including one student whose PhD dissertation addressed the goals of the project and is now a postdoctoral researcher in the field; and three undergraduate students working on the project who published as first authors of peer-reviewed articles and are now pursuing PhD's in astronomy and astrophysics at other institutions thanks to the research opportunities afforded them because of this award.
